title: 10 Easy Tips For Sticking To Your New Year's Resolutions
summary: There are many common New Yearâ€™s resolutions with a focus on habit-building, like exercising more, eating healthier, reading more or learning new skills. Starting small and building up slowly is a better way to go about it. Celebrate small wins, even if they seem insignificant at the time, and the more consistent you are with your efforts, the better the results will be. It takes time to change your habits, and you don't want to throw in the towel too soon.

What you do with that opportunity is up to you. Maybe you resolve to eat healthier, exercise more or reduce stress and anxiety. Maybe you decide to learn a new skill, read more books, help others or travel more. Or maybe your resolution is to do something completely different \u2014 like learn a language, stop procrastinating or read the complete works of Shakespeare. The possibilities are endless, but sticking to those resolutions can be challenging. The key is establishing habits that will last all 365 days of the year and not just one crazy day in January. It takes small but deliberate changes in everyday life that add up over time and become second nature. Here are 10 easy tips for sticking to your New Year\u2019s resolutions:"))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

Start by shifting your daily routine, especially if you\u2019re a person who is stuck in a daily routine that doesn\u2019t support your New Year\u2019s resolutions. If you\u2019re trying to eat healthier, you might want to consider a different grocery store or a different route home from work that gives you a different perspective. If you\u2019re trying to reduce stress and anxiety, you might want to change where you go to unwind and relax. If you go to the same place every day, you\u2019ll likely get used to it and it won\u2019t have the same effect. If you\u2019re trying to exercise more, you might want to consider a different time or day of the week. If you usually work out on a Wednesday night, try switching to a Saturday morning. If you\u2019re trying to learn a new skill, you might want to find a new place to practice \u2014 like a new coffee shop or library."),mdx("h2",null,"Write down your reasons"),mdx("p",null,"This works well for resolutions that are more about personal growth and self-awareness. If you\u2019re trying to reduce stress and anxiety, write down why that is important to you. If you\u2019re trying to read more books, write down why reading is important. If you\u2019re trying to help others more, write down why doing so is important to you. If you\u2019re trying to be more creative, write down how creativity makes you feel. If you\u2019re trying to spend more time with loved ones, write down how those relationships make you feel."),mdx("h2",null,"Make it a habit"),mdx("p",null,"There are many common New Year\u2019s resolutions with a focus on habit-building, like exercising more, eating healthier, reading more or learning new skills. Those are great to focus on, but they can also be overwhelming. It\u2019s better to look at one habit at a time and make it a part of your daily routine. Once you have that down, you can add another habit. If you try to do too much at once, it\u2019s likely you will burn out and give up. Starting small and building up slowly is a better way to go about it. If you\u2019re trying to read more, don\u2019t go from reading zero books a year to 12 books a month. Start with one book a month and build up from there. If you\u2019re trying to eat healthier, start by making one small change \u2014 like switching from white bread to whole grain bread or drinking more water. Then add a second change, and so on. If you\u2019re trying to exercise more, start with something low impact, like walking, and gradually increase the amount you do over time."),mdx("h2",null,"Celebrate small wins"),mdx("p",null,"You\u2019re bound to hit roadblocks along the way, and that\u2019s perfectly normal. Try to celebrate small wins, even if they seem insignificant at the time. If you\u2019re trying to read more, don\u2019t get frustrated if you only read one book in a month. If you\u2019re trying to eat healthier, don\u2019t get discouraged if you only stick to your new eating habits for a week. If you\u2019re trying to reduce stress and anxiety, don\u2019t get discouraged if you feel like you\u2019re not making progress. It takes time to change your habits, and you don\u2019t want to throw in the towel too soon. Be patient and consistent, and those habits will become second nature."),mdx("h2",null,"Set realistic expectations"),mdx("p",null,"It\u2019s important to set realistic expectations. If you\u2019re trying to eat healthier, don\u2019t expect to change your eating habits overnight. It takes time and patience to change your eating habits for the better. If you\u2019re trying to exercise more, don\u2019t expect to go from never exercising to training for a marathon. Start with walking or yoga and build up from there. If you\u2019re trying to read more, don\u2019t expect to read 12 books in a month. Start with one book a month and build up from there. If you\u2019re trying to reduce stress and anxiety, don\u2019t expect to change your habits overnight. These things take time, and the more consistent you are with your efforts, the better the results will be."),mdx("h2",null,"Don\u2019t forget to breathe and be in the moment"),mdx("p",null,"It\u2019s easy to get caught up in pursuing your resolutions and forget to just be in the moment. If you\u2019re trying to reduce stress and anxiety, don\u2019t forget to be in the moment. If you\u2019re trying to read more, don\u2019t forget to be in the moment. If you\u2019re trying to eat healthier, don\u2019t forget to be in the moment. All three of those resolutions require you to be in the moment, and that\u2019s the best way to reduce stress and anxiety. If you\u2019re always thinking about what you need to do next and what you did yesterday, it\u2019s easy to get stressed out and anxious. If you\u2019re trying to spend more time with loved ones, don\u2019t forget to be in the moment. Put your phone down and be there with your loved ones."),mdx("h2",null,"Commit to being better, not perfect"),mdx("p",null,"This is especially important for resolutions that are more about self-awareness and personal growth. If you\u2019re trying to reduce stress and anxiety, don\u2019t try to be perfect. If you\u2019re trying to read more, don\u2019t try to be perfect. If you\u2019re trying to help others more, don\u2019t try to be perfect. If you\u2019re trying to be more creative, don\u2019t try to be perfect. You\u2019ll only set yourself up for failure. Instead, commit to being better through daily and consistent effort. The results will be much better than if you try to be perfect. You\u2019ll learn and grow as you go, and in the end, you\u2019ll be better than you were before."),mdx("h2",null,"Don\u2019t let fear sway your decisions"),mdx("p",null,"Fear is normal, but it can also be paralyzing and hinder your progress. If you\u2019re trying to eat healthier, don\u2019t let fear sway your decisions. If you\u2019re trying to help others more, don\u2019t let fear sway your decisions. If you\u2019re trying to be more creative, don\u2019t let fear sway your decisions. If you\u2019re pursuing any New Year\u2019s resolutions, don\u2019t let fear sway your decisions. Be confident in your decisions and know that the best way to reduce stress and anxiety is to be in the moment."),mdx("h2",null,"Conclusion"),mdx("p",null,"The key to successfully sticking to your New Year\u2019s resolutions is to make small but deliberate changes in everyday life that add up over time and become second nature. It\u2019s also helpful to start small and build up slowly as it\u2019s easier to build and maintain momentum when you start small. Because their cats are hilarious. With their constant sneering and condescending glares, feline friends have a knack for being entertaining in the most ridiculous ways. So, if you need a break from those stressful final exam cram sessions, we've compiled a list of the top 10 funniest cat videos on YouTube. Cat videos are one of the most popular video niches online today. There are several channels on YouTube that are dedicated only to cat videos and nothing else. relatedArticles.title: How to Train Your Dog Not to Jump on People

Or perhaps you just don\u2019t want your dog jumping up on people. Whatever the case, teaching your dog to not jump up on people is an essential skill. It can also be tricky because it requires reading your dog and anticipating their behavior. If they haven\u2019t jumped yet, will they leap again? Will they creep towards you first or wait for you to move closer first? The answer may be different every time and that\u2019s why it can feel like a constant guessing game. However, with persistence and patience, you can train your dog to not jump on people.
If your dog is prone to jumping, it\u2019s important to manage that behavior before moving onto this training program. Dogs commonly jump for one of three reasons: They are excited and overstimulated; they want something from you such as food or attention; or they see it as a way of getting nearer to something else (this could be either the person you don\u2019t want them leaping at or something else nearby).`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Deal with a Partner Who's Always on Their Computer

It can be super easy to fall into a routine when you\u2019re spending so much time with each other. You go to work, come home, and then retreat to your respective rooms for the rest of the night. And while that routine is totally normal and understandable at this stage in your relationship, it might not be exactly what you\u2019re looking for.
It\u2019s easy to get jealous or resentful if your partner is always on their computer \u2014 but that doesn\u2019t mean that there isn\u2019t a reason for their constant use of it. It could be that they are really passionate about something they\u2019re researching online or maybe they have an online business venture they\u2019ve been working on for a while now. However, if this is causing tension between you two, speak up! They may not even realize how much time they spend on their computer and just how much of an impact it has on your relationship. Here are some ways to deal with a partner who's always on their computer:`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

It\u2019s an impartial and confidential process that helps individuals, businesses, and organizations reach mutually beneficial solutions to their conflicts. These solutions are usually in the form of agreements called \u201Cmediation agreements\u201D or \u201Ccollaborative mediation agreements.\u201D Mediation is not a one-time event but rather an ongoing process and collaboration between the disputants that involves multiple sessions.
Mediation can be used in all kinds of relationships where there is an opportunity to explore different ways of dealing with conflict and find win-win solutions without having to go to court or some other expensive third party adjudication. These include disputes between partners, shareholders, suppliers, customers, tenants, employees, suppliers and competitors; labor/management; landlord/tenant; divorcing spouses; members of nonprofit boards; roommates; feuding neighbours; business partners (and service providers); vendors (and clients); owners and real estate developers; executors and beneficiaries of trusts; owners and local governments etc.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

Parties agree to have a neutral third-party called a mediator act as an intermediary, bringing opposing parties together to resolve their dispute and avoid expensive and time-consuming court proceedings.
If you are involved in a lawsuit or other legal conflict, mediation can be beneficial in several ways. It can help you resolve your dispute faster and cheaper than going to trial. Mediation also has the potential to preserve your relationship with the other party after the dispute is resolved, which may prove useful if you anticipate interacting with that person again in the future. Lastly, mediation may give you more control over how your dispute is resolved, as opposed to leaving that up to an unpredictable judge or jury.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

It is an opportunity for people who are in a dispute to speak directly with one another, explore their differences and find common ground. Mediation is not about winning or losing; it\u2019s about finding peace so everyone can go forward with their lives.
Mediation has been used as an alternative to litigation for more than 2,500 years. The practice of mediation has continued to evolve over time and today there are many different types, including: family mediation, dispute resolution, community mediation, transformative mediation and collaborative law. However, they all have the same core elements and are intended to achieve the same goals: finding common ground between two parties in conflict; preserving personal relationships; and resolving problems constructively by using active listening techniques.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Deal with a Partner Who's Always Working

If your partner usually leaves for work before you even get out of bed, or isn\u2019t home until after you\u2019re already in bed, things can get tricky.
Working from home, flexible hours and remote working are all buzzwords in today\u2019s labor market. Companies are becoming increasingly aware that it isn\u2019t just about how much time employees spend at the desk but also about what they achieve during that time. A Gallup poll found that telecommuting or working from home is growing in popularity among professionals across most industries. Working remotely makes it easier to find jobs, negotiate schedules and live without a commute.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Train Your Dog to Come When Called

If not, are you looking for a way to improve? Coming when called is an essential command that most pet owners neglect. When your dog comes when called, it means he will come back to you right away and not run away or chase something else. This will help keep your dog safe, especially if he\u2019s prone to running away or chasing objects or other animals. It also helps with training and makes everyday interactions much easier than having to constantly chase after your pet.
But perhaps the most important reason why you should train your dog to come when called is because it might just save his life one day. In many cases, dogs that run away don\u2019t get lost, they are just trying to find a way back home. Therefore, knowing how to train your dog to come when called can be the difference between him coming home safe and sound or getting lost forever.
